</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
consider cost of goods sold to include the direct cost of merchandise, plus certain costs associated with procurement, warehousing, handling and distribution. In addition to the full
cost of inventory, cost of goods sold includes related occupancy costs and amortization and depreciation of leasehold improvements and rental equipment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
expenses include controllable and non-controllable store expenses (except occupancy), non-store expenses and depreciation and amortization not
associated with cost of goods sold. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Fiscal 2003 as compared to Fiscal 2002  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Sales.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net sales increased $709.2&nbsp;million, or 67.5%, to $1,760.4&nbsp;million in fiscal 2003, compared to
$1,051.2&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002. The sales increase reflects the inclusion of $697.0&nbsp;million in sales from TSA stores from August&nbsp;4, 2003, the merger date, versus results for Gart
Sports on a stand-alone basis in fiscal 2002. Additionally, non-comparable sales for Gart on a stand-alone basis increased $28.3&nbsp;million, net, reflecting an increase from store openings in
fiscal 2002 and fiscal 2003 of $45.6&nbsp;million, offset by a decrease of $17.3&nbsp;million, primarily from store closings. Comparable store sales in fiscal 2003, which includes TSA stores since
August&nbsp;4, 2003, decreased 0.7%, primarily due to a first quarter decline of 8.8% for Gart on a stand-alone basis. The first quarter was impacted by a comparison to increased sales from the Salt
Lake City Winter Olympics in 2002 and a decrease in sales due to a major snowstorm in the Denver area in 2003, among other factors. Sales performance improved thereafter, with relatively flat
comparable store sales in the second and fourth quarters, and a 1.7% increase in the third quarter. Focusing on results for the Company following the TSA merger, comparable store sales increased
$9.9&nbsp;million or 0.8% for the last half of the 2003 fiscal year. The </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=21,EFW="2133328",CP="THE SPORTS AUTHORITY, INC.",DN="1",CHK=375782,FOLIO='18',FILE='DISK022:[04DEN7.04DEN1607]DC1607A.;41',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='15-APR-2004;16:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dc1607_1_19"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>increase
resulted from a positive performance in the team sports, hunting and camping categories, and by strong sales in the ski, snowboard and snow apparel categories in Sports Authority locations in
the northeast. The northeast stores benefited from an expanded product offering in these categories, as the broader assortment available in Gart stores was introduced into Sports Authority
cold-weather markets. In aggregate, these factors produced a $15.9&nbsp;million or 8.0% increase in comparable store sales. Partially offsetting these gains were declines in the fitness
equipment, trends/gifts and skate categories aggregating $12.7&nbsp;million or 7.1% decrease in comp store sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross Profit.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross profit for fiscal 2003 was $485.7&nbsp;million, or 27.6% of net sales, as compared to
$274.9&nbsp;million, or 26.2% of net sales, for fiscal 2002. The increase as a percent of net sales reflected improved merchandise margins for the combined companies as a result of lower inventory
costs. Gart Sports results also improved on a stand-alone basis over the prior year, with an increase in merchandise margins of 0.5% of net sales. The increase reflects a somewhat less promotional
selling environment in fiscal 2003 than in the prior year combined with reduced inventory costs, which produced improvements in merchandise margin rates in a number of categories. These categories
include fitness equipment, snowboards, hunting and camping, which produced a combined increase in merchandise margin rates of 90 basis points. In addition, the application of EITF Consensus
No.&nbsp;02-16, "Accounting by a Customer (Including a Reseller) for Certain Consideration Received from a Vendor" ("EITF 02-16") resulted in the recharacterization of
$3.0&nbsp;million of vendor allowances, from a reduction of advertising expense to a reduction of the cost of inventory purchased, of which $2.1&nbsp;million, or 0.1% of net sales, was recognized
in cost of goods sold in fiscal 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating expenses in fiscal 2003 were $409.5&nbsp;million, or 23.3% of net sales, compared to
$229.0&nbsp;million, or 21.8% of net sales, for fiscal 2002. The increase in operating expense dollars primarily reflects the store operating costs associated with 205 TSA stores acquired on
August&nbsp;4, 2003. Operating expenses also increased as a percent of sales due to the following factors: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(i)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>TSA
Stores' overall operating expenses historically trended higher than Gart's. TSA Stores' selling, general and administrative expenses were 26.0%, 25.5% and 24.6% of
net sales in 2002, 2001 an 2000, compared to Gart's operating expenses of 21.8% of net sales for each of fiscal 2002 and 2001, and 21.9% of net sales for fiscal 2000. The implementation of consistent
operating procedures for the combined company is an ongoing process that we expect to have completed by the end of fiscal 2004;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(ii)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
higher level of general and administrative costs as a result of the TSA merger, including insurance costs, which increased $2.8&nbsp;million, and corporate office
rent, which increased $1.7&nbsp;million due to additional leased office space to accommodate our larger corporate offices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(iii)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
recharacterization of $3.0&nbsp;million, or 0.2% of net sales, of cooperative advertising monies from a reduction of advertising expense to a reduction of
inventory costs as required by EITF 02-16; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(iv)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Establishing
a reserve for the settlement of wage and hour class action lawsuits in California totaling $1.5&nbsp;million, including attorney fees and expenses,
recorded in the first quarter of 2003. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Merger Integration Costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Merger integration costs for fiscal 2003 were $43.8&nbsp;million, or 2.5% of net sales, and were
related to the TSA merger. Integration costs include only non-recurring, incremental costs arising as a direct result of integrating the two companies following the merger. For fiscal
2003, these costs consisted of $17.7&nbsp;million of duplicative payroll, benefits and retention payments, $8.4&nbsp;million of severance costs, $6.7&nbsp;million of consulting fees,
$6.0&nbsp;million of expense related to winding up the operations of the TSA corporate office in Ft. Lauderdale and closing a Gart store in an overlapping market, $3.0&nbsp;million for relocation
and travel, and $2.0&nbsp;million of advertising related to rebranding and announcing the combined company. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=22,EFW="2133328",CP="THE SPORTS AUTHORITY, INC.",DN="1",CHK=298780,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK022:[04DEN7.04DEN1607]DC1607A.;41',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='15-APR-2004;16:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dc1607_1_20"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Income.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the factors described above, operating income for fiscal 2003 was $32.9&nbsp;million, or
1.9% of net sales, compared to $45.9&nbsp;million, or 4.4% of net sales, in fiscal 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense for fiscal 2003 increased to $12.3&nbsp;million, or 0.7% of net sales, from
$9.2&nbsp;million, or 0.9% of net sales, in the prior year. The increase in interest expense is related to the assumption of TSA Stores' debt upon completion of the merger and to financing of merger
and integration costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income was $3.5&nbsp;million for fiscal 2003 compared to $1.1&nbsp;million for fiscal 2002. The
increase is primarily attributable to interest income associated with the settlement of the Rite Aid tax dispute totaling $2.1&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our income tax expense for fiscal 2003 was $7.7&nbsp;million compared to $14.6&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002.
Tax expense for fiscal 2003 was offset by a tax benefit of $1.7&nbsp;million recorded as a result of the settlement with our former parent regarding an IRS examination of our 1992 and 1993
consolidated federal income tax returns. Excluding this one-time benefit, the Company's estimated tax rate was approximately 39% for both fiscal 2003 and fiscal 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Fiscal 2002 as compared to Fiscal 2001  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Sales.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net sales increased $115.5&nbsp;million, or 12.3%, to $1,051.2&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 compared to
$935.7&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001. Sales in fiscal 2001 include Oshman's results after the June&nbsp;7, 2001 acquisition date compared to a full year of results for the combined company in fiscal
2002, resulting in
an increase of fiscal 2002 net sales of approximately $92.0&nbsp;million or 8.8%. New stores contributed approximately $23.5&nbsp;million in net sales, or 2.2%, for fiscal 2002. Comparable store
sales in fiscal 2002, which included the Oshman's stores from August&nbsp;4, 2002, were flat, reflecting several offsetting factors throughout the year. In the first quarter of 2002, comparable
store sales were strong due to a strong late ski season in our cold-weather markets, sales of merchandise related to the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City and increased exercise equipment
promotions. The second quarter reflected a general decline in business, and a significant decline in the camping and hunting departments due to drought and forest fire activity in the Rocky Mountain
Region and the western United States. Third quarter 2002 sales increases were driven by licensed apparel sales as teams in our markets were involved in the Major League Baseball World Series and
playoffs. However, these increases were offset by a soft selling environment in the fourth quarter of 2002, combined with a mild winter, which impacted our outdoor apparel sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross Profit.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross profit for fiscal 2002 was $274.9&nbsp;million, or 26.2% of net sales, as compared to
$239.4&nbsp;million, or 25.6% of net sales, for fiscal 2001. The increase as a percent of sales is due to a number of factors including: a less promotional strategy taken during the year; synergies
realized from the Oshman's acquisition; systems investments, allowing us to better manage in-stock positions; and the addition of key personnel in the buying organization, particularly in
the softlines department. Due to the nature of these items, they cannot be independently quantified. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating expenses in fiscal 2002 were $229.0&nbsp;million, or 21.8% of net sales, compared to
$204.4&nbsp;million, or 21.8% of net sales, for fiscal 2001. Fiscal 2002 reflects a full year of operating expenses related to the Oshman's stores, while fiscal 2001 includes only results after the
June&nbsp;7, 2001, the acquisition date. As a percentage of sales, operating expenses were flat year over year, due to a continued focus on controlling costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Merger Integration Costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Merger integration costs were $12.5&nbsp;million, or 1.4% of net sales, for fiscal 2001 and
related to the Oshman's acquisition. These costs include $3.6&nbsp;million of duplicative or retention payroll and benefits, $3.0&nbsp;million of advertising related to rebranding and announcing
the combined company, $1.5&nbsp;million for outside consulting services related to the integration, $2.3&nbsp;million </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=23,EFW="2133328",CP="THE SPORTS AUTHORITY, INC.",DN="1",CHK=173679,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK022:[04DEN7.04DEN1607]DC1607A.;41',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='15-APR-2004;16:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dc1607_1_21"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>of
costs associated with consolidating and relocating the corporate offices, and the balance principally for other corporate office costs, travel and employee relocation and other personnel costs. We
incurred no further merger integration costs related to the Oshman's acquisition since the fourth quarter of fiscal 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Income.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the factors described above, operating income for fiscal 2002 was $45.9&nbsp;million or
4.4% of net sales compared to $22.5&nbsp;million or 2.4% of net sales in fiscal 2001. Fiscal 2002 operating income increased $10.9&nbsp;million, or 0.7% of sales, when compared to fiscal 2001
operating income excluding integration costs of $35.0&nbsp;million or 3.7% of sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense for fiscal 2002 decreased to $9.2&nbsp;million, or 0.9% of net sales, from
$11.0&nbsp;million, or 1.2% of net sales, in the prior year. The decrease in interest expenses is related to lower effective borrowing rates on amounts borrowed in 2002, resulting in approximately
$2.7&nbsp;million in interest savings, a settlement with the IRS in the third quarter of 2002 reducing interest expense by $0.7&nbsp;million, and an increase to interest expense of
$1.6&nbsp;million due to an overall higher average debt balance, resulting from a decrease in the average debt as a result of the net proceeds from the May&nbsp;2002 common stock offering, offset
by the increased average debt due to the acquisition of Oshman's on June&nbsp;7, 2001 and the shares repurchased under the 2002 common share repurchase program. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income was $1.1&nbsp;million for fiscal 2002 compared to $2.1&nbsp;million for fiscal 2001. The
decrease is primarily attributable to non-recurring items recorded in fiscal 2001, including $0.7&nbsp;million of income related to a consulting services agreement, $0.3&nbsp;million
of income recognized on the sales of marketable securities, and a one-time gain of $0.2&nbsp;million on the sale of certain assets that were held in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. These
items were offset primarily by increased sales tax handling income in the current year of approximately $0.2&nbsp;million, due to increased sales volume as a result of the acquisition of Oshman's. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our income tax expense for fiscal 2002 was $14.6&nbsp;million compared to $5.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001.
Our effective tax rate for fiscal 2002 was 38.7% compared to 39.0% in fiscal 2001, reflecting changes in certain permanent tax differences as compared to fiscal 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our primary capital requirements are for inventory and other seasonal working capital needs, capital improvements, including investments in store remodeling,
store fixtures and ongoing infrastructure improvements, and pre-opening expenses to support our expansion plans. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dc1607_cash_flow_analysis"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dc1607_5"> </A>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>0.61</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=24,EFW="2133328",CP="THE SPORTS AUTHORITY, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1025095,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK022:[04DEN7.04DEN1607]DC1607A.;41',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='15-APR-2004;16:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dc1607_1_22"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
provided by operating activities increased $25.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2003 compared to fiscal 2002. The increase is primarily due to a higher level of accounts payable financing
in fiscal 2003, only partially offset by an increase in inventories, producing a net $39.4&nbsp;million improvement in operating cash flows year over year. Additionally, net income adjusted to
exclude depreciation and amortization increased by $8.1&nbsp;million over fiscal 2002. These increases in operating cash flows were partially offset by an increase in accounts receivable of
$13.0&nbsp;million due to increased vendor entitlement receivables. In fiscal 2002, the increase in cash provided by operations compared to fiscal 2001 is due to an increase in net income adjusted
to exclude depreciation and amortization. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
used in investing activities increased $79.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2003 compared to fiscal 2002. The change reflects an increase in capital expenditures in fiscal 2003 of
$41.7&nbsp;million, combined with TSA merger costs (net of cash acquired) of $42.8&nbsp;million offset by the receipt of $5.1&nbsp;million on the sale-leaseback of a TSA store site.
Additionally, we entered into a second sale-leaseback transaction of a TSA store site in January&nbsp;2004, while the proceeds of $10.9&nbsp;million were received on the first business
day of fiscal 2004. Total capital expenditures were $67.6&nbsp;million in fiscal 2003, and included: $24.2&nbsp;million for expanding and remodeling the corporate office and improvements and
upgrades to our information and POS systems; $20.9&nbsp;million for the development of 17 new or relocated stores, and for stores planned to be opened in early fiscal 2004; and $20.2&nbsp;million
for refurbishment, remodel and general capital improvements of existing stores. Cash used in investing activities declined $38.6&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 versus 2001, reflecting
non-recurring acquisition costs in fiscal 2001 of $49.9&nbsp;million related to the Oshman's acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
provided by financing activities, which typically consists principally of net borrowings or payments under our revolving credit facility, increased $73.2&nbsp;million in fiscal
2003 compared to fiscal 2002. The increase reflects additional borrowings required to finance TSA merger costs and the higher level of capital expenditures in fiscal 2003 not otherwise financed by
operating cash flows. Proceeds from stock option exercises were $9.9&nbsp;million in fiscal 2003 compared to $2.7&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002, consistent with the increase in stock option
exercises due to acceleration of vesting of TSA options as a result of the merger. In fiscal 2002, cash flows from financing activities other than stock option exercises were relatively neutral as
proceeds from our secondary common stock offering were used to pay down long-term debt. By comparison, financing cash flows of $55.8&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001 reflected the higher
level of borrowings required to finance the Oshman's acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Working
capital was $378.9&nbsp;million as of January&nbsp;31, 2004 compared to $171.8&nbsp;million as of February&nbsp;1, 2003, an increase of $207.1&nbsp;million. The
increase is due principally to an increase in inventories net of accounts payable of $169.5&nbsp;million year over year, reflecting additional stores acquired in the TSA merger. Additionally,
current deferred income taxes increased $80.0&nbsp;million, reflecting tax assets generated in connection with the TSA merger and tax assets acquired from the former Sports Authority. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
liquidity and capital needs have principally been met by operating cash flows and by borrowings under a revolving credit facility with CIT/Business Credit,&nbsp;Inc. ("CIT"), as
agent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
consummation of the merger, we entered into a new credit financing agreement (the "Credit Agreement") with CIT, as agent, that allows us to borrow up to $600,000,000, limited to an
amount equal to 70% of eligible inventory or 85% of the appraised net orderly liquidation value of eligible inventory (as defined in the agreement). We are also entitled to seasonal increases in the
inventory advance rate for up to 120&nbsp;days during any calendar year as designated by us for the lesser of 80% of eligible inventory or 90% of appraised net orderly liquidation value. Borrowings
are secured by substantially all present and future accounts (as defined in the Credit Agreement), inventories, trade receivables, equipment, documents of title and intangible assets. The borrowings
mature, absent an occurrence of default under the agreement, on August&nbsp;4, 2007. The Credit Agreement contains certain covenants, including financial covenants that require us to maintain a
specified minimum level earnings </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=25,EFW="2133328",CP="THE SPORTS AUTHORITY, INC.",DN="1",CHK=717649,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK022:[04DEN7.04DEN1607]DC1607A.;41',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='15-APR-2004;16:02' -->
<A NAME="page_dc1607_1_23"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>before
interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization to interest ratios if we do not have at least $50&nbsp;million available for borrowing in the first year, $60&nbsp;million in the second year
and $75&nbsp;million thereafter. In addition, the Credit Agreement restricts, among other things, our ability to incur additional debt, to merge, consolidate or sell assets, to make loans or
advances to others, to guaranty obligations of others, to pledge our assets, to make certain investments, and to engage in transactions with affiliates. Our ability to declare or pay dividends on our
common stock and to repurchase our common stock is limited to $16&nbsp;million per year under the Credit Agreement. We are in compliance with all covenants under the Credit Agreement. In connection
with the Credit Agreement, we pledged all of the outstanding common stock of our subsidiaries, including TSA Stores,&nbsp;Inc. our principal operating retail subsidiary, as collateral for the Credit
Agreement. Interest is payable monthly at Chase Manhattan Bank's prime rate plus a margin rate ranging from 0% to 0.50% or, at our option, at Chase Manhattan Bank's LIBOR rate plus a margin rate
ranging from 1.50% to 2.50%. At January&nbsp;31, 2004, there was $317.3&nbsp;million outstanding under the Credit Agreement and $139.5&nbsp;million was available for borrowing. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital
expenditures are projected to be approximately $85&nbsp;million in fiscal 2004, primarily for the opening of approximately 23 new stores and relocation of two stores,
remodeling of approximately 70 stores, principally Sports Authority stores; completion of a new distribution center in Fontana, California, and refurbishment of the existing Sports Authority
distribution centers, and information systems upgrades and enhancements and ongoing Sports Authority systems integration. We lease the majority of our store locations and intend to continue to finance
our new store construction with long-term operating leases. Based upon recent store openings, newly constructed superstores require a cash investment of approximately $1.6&nbsp;million
for a 42,000 square foot store and approximately $1.3&nbsp;million for a 32,000 square foot store. The level of capital improvements will be affected by the mix of new construction versus renovation
of existing retail space. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
believe that cash generated from operations, combined with funds available under the revolving credit facility, will be sufficient to fund projected capital expenditures, future
common share purchases, if any, and other working capital requirements for the foreseeable future. We intend to utilize the revolving credit facility to meet seasonal fluctuations in cash flow
requirements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>We
have routine commitments under merchandise inventory purchase orders, which vary in amount from month to month depending on seasonality and other factors. Such purchase orders are
cancelable by us without payment. In addition, we have entered into employment agreements with each of our executive officers. Payments under these employment agreements are dependent on these
executives providing future services and certain payments are required to be made upon termination of employment by us without cause, as defined in the employment agreements. These items have not been
included in the amounts in the above table. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Interest Rate and Foreign Currency Risk Management  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We entered into an interest rate swap agreement on June&nbsp;28, 2001, expiring on June&nbsp;30, 2004, and entered into a second interest rate swap agreement
on December&nbsp;11, 2002, expiring on May&nbsp;31, 2005, to minimize the risks and costs associated with our financing activities. Under the swap agreements, we pay fixed rate interest and
receive variable LIBOR interest rate payments periodically over the life of the agreements. The total notional amounts under the interest rate swaps are $60&nbsp;million, which do not represent the
exposure due to credit loss. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
interest rate swaps are designated as cash flow hedges and are considered highly effective, as defined by FASB Statement No.&nbsp;133. Net settlements on the swap agreements are
recorded as interest expense. At January&nbsp;31, 2004, the fair value of the swap agreements was a loss of $759,000, net of the related tax benefit. The unrealized loss from these interest rate
swaps is included in other comprehensive income and is a component of stockholders' equity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
exposure to foreign currency risk is not material. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

only of normal recurring adjustments) necessary for a fair presentation of the information for the periods presented. The results of operations for any quarter are not necessarily indicative of the
results for any future period. </FONT></P>

results for the last two quarters of fiscal year 2003 are not comparable to the other periods presented due to the inclusion of The Sports Authority results of operations, after
